This course was interesting but wasn't as engaging as I would have liked but is very laid-back.

The course provided insight into the types of research people are doing that pertains to SBS. I do think having speakers who are in non-research positions would be helpful in giving us a sense of what we could do outside of academia.
In addition, I do think the schedule was a little confusing. I know it changed in the middle of the semester, but it was difficult to know which seminars were mandatory and which were optional.
I appreciated it. We had some wonderful speakers! The topics were always immensely interesting.

Eh. Nothing special. I wish there was more community building. It is more of a sit around, wait for the hour glass to run out and then bolt. It is nothing beyond that. There should also be some vetting of the talks...

This course is really great it that it provided you with a lot of information about a wide variety of subjects. The speakers are all very interesting and really enjoyable to hear from. The one downside is that the schedule is very confusing, it changes a bunch and we had a mandatory session on a different day than we normally do, which makes it difficult to schedule things and make it to the seminar.

Another weakness is that we have this same food like all of the time. Some variety would be very appreciated.
usually insightful, great healthy food options
I enjoyed the diversity of speakers as well as the few sessions dedicated to feedback, the internship search, etc.
The speakers this semester were interesting and I appreciated the range of topics (e.g. social networks, community-based projects, health in incarceration/re-entry) and the vastly improved lunch!
N/A

Strengths of this course highlight work that would be relevant to students in the SBS department. It would be great to see more research that are in different fields to learn how we can intersect both at the research and policy level.
Great Thursday seminar that was informative, relaxing, and offered lunch!

This was a great course. I enjoyed the presenters. However, there could have been more communication about class attendance requirements. There were also some date related snafus that hindered my ability to attend class. There was one day in which the date and day of the week did not match, and another week there were 2 sessions, but one was barely advertised and not on the original date list. It seems unfair to add a "mandatory" session like this.
The food provided in the seminar was excellent. The guest lecturers were very interesting and I think the seminar would have benefited from having more guest lecturers throughout the semester.
I thought the readings and topics were fascinating, but it was difficult to engage with the material to the level I would have liked in a class that big.
Interesting speakers that presented on a wide variety of SBS subjects

There was clearly careful planning of each seminar, which I appreciated. I also always appreciated the food. I think it would have been helpful to make the seminars 90 minutes instead because the speakers hardly ever left time for questions. Those last 5 minutes (because that's usually all that was left) did not feel conducive for engagement and so few students did and it just became a pattern. The topics that were covered were really interesting, especially the second half. I gained the most from seeing the decision-making process for each of their areas of study and the work they subsequently produced.
As a second year, was only required to attend one session for the thesis which was helpful.  The brown bag lunches are also always a nice way to gauge how other students are feeling in the semester.

good course, I'm glad we have a departmental seminar. Some of the calendars/emails conflicted on what was mandatory and what was not so I think clarifying that would be helpful. Really enjoyed the chili meals, not so much the quiche and kale salad :) I enjoyed the speakers who were brought in.

The seminar was fantastic. I think it was a nice mix of people and issues all relating to the social and behavioral sciences. It shows the wide opportunities that this concentration provides. All of the speakers were great and engaging. As well, the lunch opportunities afterward are a great opportunity to meet people working in the field and ask more specific questions.
The seminars were informative and informed, and the experts who were invited to lecture provided a thoughtful and insightful commentary to crucial topics in public health.

I was always interested in the topic and I appreciate that the SBS department is so engaged. My only critique to please please please have some diversity with the food. The kale apple salad is good but not good enough to have everyday. I know a lot of people were grateful to get food but were upset it was the same every week.

I rarely felt the level of interaction between colleagues in this seminar that I have in seminars I've taken in the past, which I think to a degree was due to esoteric subject matter addressed by each individual speaker. This course also often felt like checking a box off of a list of requirements. I wonder if allowing students to choose 5 seminars from any of our departments -- rather than strictly our own -- might lend itself to a more interdisciplinary public health approach and enable students to engage directly with material relevant to their professional and academic goals.

I should also point out that scheduling was consistently problematic. We would often receive emails notifying us of a seminar that previously was not listed as "required" only for that stipulation to change at the last minute. I was frequently confused by expectations as to when we were and were not supposed to be attending seminars.
Great facilitator.
Professor Wang is very courteous and very nice. She's very open to letting students ask the speakers questions.
Her speaker introductions and questions were great!
N/A
Good!
Katie is wonderful! She responded to my emails immediately and always has an answer!
Great facilitator.
His speaker introductions and questions were great!
N/A
Good!

Yusuf did a great job. It is clear to see that he is incredibly respected both within the SBS department and by the lecturers. He is engaged throughout the whole lecture and asks great questions, setting an example for the students in the classroom.
Never really communicated with him.
This course is interesting in learning more about other people's work. I would recommend it to another student because it is laid-back, simple and interesting.
This is a required class for SBS students and is a completion of guest lecturers. I found the speakers to be engaging and thought provoking.

This seminar invites public health practitioners and researchers to prevent their work in front of students who are concentrating in SBS. It is mandatory for first year students, yet many second year students come as well. Lunch is provided, and the conversation is always interesting and lively following the presentations.
Eh
You hear from a lot of interesting speakers an you learn a lot, it's fun to go to because there is always something interesting to hear.
I would recommend going to this for the tasty lunch and to hear the speakers if you are interested in the speaker topic of that day.
N/A
I would recommend to another student to learn more about the SBS field within PH. It gives an insight into the work of many PH professionals.
Yes I would recommend -- a good time to get see other SBS students and learn about an interesting topic in a relaxed environment.
Yes
Yes
I would definitely recommend all SBS students to attend seminar.
Laid back and enjoyable. Would recommend!
This course was great. These lectures are a great way to understand potential opportunities of research and future growth of the field. Yes, I would recommend this to other students.

This course is consists of weekly seminars over lunch targeted towards public health students within the Social and Behavioral Sciences Department (SBS). It is a combination of lectures given by public health experts who focus on social and behavioral sciences and information sessions for SBS students regarding important matters within our curriculum such as the master's thesis. I would recommend this to another student, because it is an opportunity to learn new, interesting materials about public health that reinforce and add on to the concepts we cover in class. The weekly free lunch is also great!
You come to seminar, eat food, listen to the seminar discuss and leave. It was simple and it was a good break from the craziness of the week.

This is a micro series of classes that focuses on esoteric subjects relating to social and behavioral sciences. Much of the discussion will revolve around presentations given by colleagues from other institutions.
